item.title: Python Blog
item.description: Oh python, how we love you so!! But for real, are data processing programs not the coolest and most mind boggling technology you've ever seen. They literally have such endless capabilities!! As I have recently gained more knowledge regarding the functions of Python, one handy tip has stood out to me. Drum roll please..... Tip = The fact that strings in Python are immutable. Basically, you can assign a string to a variable name and then in some way alter that string.

item.title: Project 2: Modeling, Testing, and Predicting
item.description: wife<- read.csv("https://vincentarelbundock.github.io/Rdatasets/csv/Ecdat/Workinghours.csv") This dataset contains data that was collected from working women. It contains 12 columns and 3382 observations. There are 8 numeric variables. The numbers of hours the wife works, her household income (in hundreds of dollars), her age, the number of children she has between ages 0-5, 6-13, and 14-17, her local unemployment rate, and lastly her education years. There is one categorical variable, occupation of her husband.

item.title: project1
item.description: R Markdown This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com. When you click the Knit button a document will be generated that includes both content as well as the output of any embedded R code chunks within the document.
